===Etymology 1===
From {{inh|en|enm|Mars}}, from {{der|en|la|Mars||god of war}}, from older Latin (older than 75 {{BC}}) {{m|la|MÄvors}}. {{m|osc|ğŒŒğŒ€ğŒŒğŒ„ğŒ“ğŒ”}} was his [[w:Oscan language|Oscan]] name. He was also known as ''Marmor'', ''Marmar'' and ''Maris'', the latter from the Etruscan deity [[Maris]].

==Latin==

===Etymology===
From {{m+|itc-ola|MÄvors}}, from {{inh|la|itc-pro|*MÄwortis}}. ''Mamers'' was his [[w:Oscan language|Oscan]] name. He was also known as ''Marmor'', ''Marmar'' and ''Maris'', the latter from the Etruscan deity [[Maris]].

===Pronunciation===
* {{la-IPA|MÄrs}}

===Proper noun===
{{la-proper noun|MÄrs<3>|g=m}}

# {{senseid|la|Q111}}{{topics|la|Planets of the Solar System}}{{l|en|Mars}} (planet)
# {{senseid|la|Q112}}{{topics|la|Roman deities}}[[#English|Mars]] (Roman god)

===Usage notes===
The name of the god could, through {{m|la|interpretatio romana}}, serve to replace the name of a war god in a foreign language. Thus [[w:Saxo Grammaticus|Saxo Grammaticus]], for example, uses the term to refer to the Norse god [[Odin]], alternating it with the borrowed form {{m|la|ÅŒthinus}}.

====Declension====
{{la-ndecl|MÄrs<3>}}

===Noun===
{{la-noun|MÄrs<3.both>|g=m}}

# [[war]], [[battle]], [[conflict]]

====Declension====
{{la-ndecl|MÄrs<3.both>}}
